article:
**R/place**

R/place is a dynamic and collaborative online artwork that was first introduced as an experiment by the social media platform Reddit in 2017. The project has since been recreated and updated in 2022 and 2023, allowing users to contribute to a large, pixelated canvas in real-time. This article provides an overview of the R/place experiment, its history, media response, and notable features.

**Overview**

R/place is a digital art project that allows users to contribute to a large, 1000x1000 pixel canvas. The canvas is divided into a grid of squares, each of which can be colored by a user. The project is designed to be collaborative, allowing users to interact with each other and create a shared artwork. The R/place project has been recreated and updated multiple times, each with its own unique features and challenges.

**History**

### 2017 experiment

The first R/place experiment was conducted in 2017 as a test of Reddit's real-time collaboration tools. The project was announced by Reddit's CEO Steve Huffman on April 30, 2017, and went live on May 3, 2017. The experiment allowed users to contribute to a 1000x1000 pixel canvas, with each user able to color a single square at a time. The project was designed to run for 72 hours, but it ended up running for over a week due to its popularity.

During the 2017 experiment, the R/place canvas was filled with a variety of images and designs, including flags, logos, and even a crude drawing of Reddit's mascot, Snoo. The project also saw the emergence of user-created memes and jokes, which were often used to represent different communities and interests. Despite its short lifespan, the 2017 R/place experiment was a huge success, with millions of users participating and contributing to the canvas.

### 2022 experiment

The second R/place experiment was conducted in 2022, six years after the first experiment. The project was announced on April 1, 2022, and went live on April 10, 2022. The 2022 experiment saw significant improvements over the 2017 version, including a larger canvas size (2000x2000 pixels), more user-friendly interface, and additional features such as user profiles and chat functionality.

The 2022 experiment also saw the emergence of new user-created content, including intricate designs, artwork, and even a fully-functional 3D model of the Reddit logo. The project was again a huge success, with millions of users participating and contributing to the canvas. However, the project also saw controversy and debate, with some users criticizing the project's moderation policies and others accusing the project of promoting hate speech.

### 2023 experiment

The third R/place experiment was conducted in 2023, one year after the 2022 experiment. The project was announced on March 1, 2023, and went live on March 10, 2023. The 2023 experiment saw further improvements over the 2022 version, including a even larger canvas size (3000x3000 pixels), additional features such as user-generated stickers and emojis, and improved moderation tools.

The 2023 experiment also saw the emergence of new user-created content, including complex designs, artwork, and even a fully-functional virtual reality experience. The project was again a huge success, with millions of users participating and contributing to the canvas. However, the project also saw controversy and debate, with some users criticizing the project's moderation policies and others accusing the project of promoting misinformation.

**Media response**

The R/place project has received widespread media attention and coverage, with many major news outlets and publications writing about the project and its users. The project has been featured on the front pages of The New York Times, The Guardian, and The Washington Post, among others. The project has also been covered by major tech and gaming outlets, including Wired, Forbes, and Kotaku.

The project's users have also been featured in various media outlets, including interviews and profiles in The Verge, The Huffington Post, and CNN. The project's users have been praised for their creativity, community spirit, and commitment to the project. However, the project has also faced criticism and controversy, with some users accusing the project of promoting hate speech and others criticizing the project's moderation policies.

title: Display_resolution_standards
article:
Display Resolution Standards
==========================

Display resolution standards refer to the width and height of an image, measured in pixels, that a display device is capable of rendering. These standards have evolved over time to accommodate the increasing demand for higher quality and higher resolution displays.

### Overview

Display resolution standards have become an essential aspect of modern technology, particularly in the fields of computing, television, and mobile devices. The primary goal of these standards is to provide a consistent and high-quality viewing experience across different platforms and devices. The evolution of display resolution standards has been driven by advances in technology, including improvements in display manufacturing, graphics processing, and compression algorithms.

### Aspect Ratio

Aspect ratio refers to the ratio of the width of an image to its height. Common aspect ratios include 4:3, 16:9, and 21:9. The most commonly used aspect ratio is 16:9, which is widely adopted in modern displays, including HDTVs, monitors, and mobile devices. Aspect ratio is an important consideration in display resolution standards, as it affects the way an image is displayed and perceived by the viewer.

### High-Definition

High-definition (HD) resolutions are characterized by a minimum of 720 horizontal pixels. There are several HD resolutions, each with its own unique characteristics and applications.

#### 640 × 360 (nHD)

640 × 360 is a non-standard HD resolution that is often used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and is commonly used in smartphones and tablets.

#### 960 × 540 (qHD)

960 × 540 is a quad high-definition (QHD) resolution that is commonly used in mid-range smartphones and tablets. It offers a higher pixel density than standard HD resolutions and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1280 × 720 (HD)

1280 × 720 is a standard HD resolution that is widely adopted in HDTVs, monitors, and mobile devices. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and productivity.

#### 1600 × 900 (HD+)

1600 × 900 is a high-definition plus (HD+) resolution that is commonly used in high-end smartphones and tablets. It offers a higher pixel density than standard HD resolutions and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and productivity.

#### 1920 × 1080 (FHD)

1920 × 1080 is a full high-definition (FHD) resolution that is widely adopted in HDTVs, monitors, and mobile devices. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and productivity.

#### 2048 × 1080 (DCI 2K)

2048 × 1080 is a DCI 2K resolution that is commonly used in professional video production and post-production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including film and television production.

#### 2560 × 1080 (UWFHD)

2560 × 1080 is an ultra-wide full high-definition (UWFHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 2560 × 1440 (QHD)

2560 × 1440 is a quad high-definition (QHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

##### 5120 × 1440 DQHD

5120 × 1440 is a double quad high-definition (DQHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 3200 × 1800 (QHD+)

3200 × 1800 is a quad high-definition plus (QHD+) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 3440 × 1440 (UWQHD)

3440 × 1440 is an ultra-wide quad high-definition (UWQHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 3840 × 1080

3840 × 1080 is an ultra-wide full high-definition (UWFHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 3840 × 1600

3840 × 1600 is an ultra-wide full high-definition (UWFHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 3840 × 2160 (4K UHD)

3840 × 2160 is a 4K ultra-high-definition (4K UHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 4096 × 2160 (DCI 4K)

4096 × 2160 is a DCI 4K resolution that is commonly used in professional video production and post-production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including film and television production.

#### 5120 × 2160

5120 × 2160 is an ultra-wide 4K resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 5120 × 2880 (5K)

5120 × 2880 is a 5K resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

#### 7680 × 4320 (8K UHD)

7680 × 4320 is an 8K ultra-high-definition (8K UHD) resolution that is commonly used in high-end gaming and video production applications. It offers a high pixel density and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming, video playback, and post-production.

### Video Graphics Array (VGA and derivatives)

Video Graphics Array (VGA) is a display standard that was introduced in the 1980s. It is characterized by a resolution of 640 × 480 pixels. There are several VGA derivatives, each with its own unique characteristics and applications.

#### 160 × 120 (QQVGA)

160 × 120 is a quarter-quarter video graphics array (QQVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 240 × 160

240 × 160 is a quarter video graphics array (QVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 3:2 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 320 × 240 (QVGA)

320 × 240 is a quarter video graphics array (QVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 400 × 240 (WQVGA)

400 × 240 is a wide quarter video graphics array (WQVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 5:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 480 × 320 (HVGA)

480 × 320 is a half video graphics array (HVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 3:2 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 640 × 480 (VGA)

640 × 480 is a video graphics array (VGA) resolution that is commonly used in monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 800 × 480 (WVGA)

800 × 480 is a wide video graphics array (WVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 5:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 854 × 480 (FWVGA)

854 × 480 is a full wide video graphics array (FWVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 800 × 600 (SVGA)

800 × 600 is a super video graphics array (SVGA) resolution that is commonly used in monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1024 × 576, 1024 × 600 (WSVGA)

1024 × 576 and 1024 × 600 are wide super video graphics array (WSVGA) resolutions that are commonly used in monitors and video conferencing applications. They are characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and are suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 960 × 640

960 × 640 is a wide video graphics array (WVGA) resolution that is commonly used in mobile devices and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 3:2 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1280 × 960 (QuadVGA)

1280 × 960 is a quad video graphics array (QuadVGA) resolution that is commonly used in monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

### Extended Graphics Array (XGA and derivatives)

Extended Graphics Array (XGA) is a display standard that was introduced in the 1990s. It is characterized by a resolution of 1024 × 768 pixels. There are several XGA derivatives, each with its own unique characteristics and applications.

#### 1024 × 768 (XGA)

1024 × 768 is an extended graphics array (XGA) resolution that is commonly used in monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### WXGA

WXGA resolutions are a series of display standards that are characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio. They are commonly used in wide-screen monitors and video conferencing applications.

#### 1366 × 768 (WXGA)

1366 × 768 is a wide extended graphics array (WXGA) resolution that is commonly used in wide-screen monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1280 × 800 (WXGA)

1280 × 800 is a wide extended graphics array (WXGA) resolution that is commonly used in wide-screen monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### Other WXGA

There are several other WXGA resolutions, each with its own unique characteristics and applications.

#### 1152 × 864 (XGA+)

1152 × 864 is an extended graphics array plus (XGA+) resolution that is commonly used in monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1440 × 900 (WXGA+, WSXGA)

1440 × 900 is a wide extended graphics array plus (WXGA+) resolution that is commonly used in wide-screen monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1600 × 1024

1600 × 1024 is a wide extended graphics array (WXGA) resolution that is commonly used in wide-screen monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1280 × 854

1280 × 854 is a wide extended graphics array (WXGA) resolution that is commonly used in wide-screen monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 16:9 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1280 × 1024 (SXGA)

1280 × 1024 is a super extended graphics array (SXGA) resolution that is commonly used in high-resolution monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 5:4 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1400 × 1050 (SXGA+)

1400 × 1050 is a super extended graphics array plus (SXGA+) resolution that is commonly used in high-resolution monitors and video conferencing applications. It is characterized by a 4:3 aspect ratio and is suitable for a variety of applications, including gaming and video playback.

#### 1680 × 1050 (WSXGA+)

**2023 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships**

The 2023 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships was the 46th edition of the IIHF World Junior Ice Hockey Championships, held from December 26, 2022, to January 5, 2023, in Halifax, Nova Scotia, and Moncton, New Brunswick, Canada.

**Top Division**

The top division was contested by 10 teams, which were divided into two groups of five teams each.

### Venues

The tournament was played in two venues:

* **Scotiabank Centre** (Moncton, New Brunswick): Capacity 7,028
* **Halifax Scotiabank Centre** (Halifax, Nova Scotia): Capacity 10,595

### Rosters

Each team was allowed to have a maximum of 22 skaters and two goalies on its roster.

### Match officials

The tournament featured a total of 14 referees and 7 linesmen.

### Teams

The top division teams were:

*  Canada (hosts)
*  Finland
*  Sweden
*  Czech Republic
*  Slovakia
*  Russia
*  United States
*  Switzerland
*  Latvia
*  Germany

article:
The Batman (film)

The Batman is a 2022 superhero film directed by Matt Reeves and produced by DC Films, Atlas Entertainment, and 6th & Idaho. The film stars Robert Pattinson as Bruce Wayne/Batman, Zoë Kravitz as Selina Kyle/Catwoman, and Paul Dano as the Riddler.

Plot
-----

The film is a reboot of the Batman film series and a standalone story that explores the early days of Bruce Wayne's crime-fighting career. The story begins with a series of gruesome murders in Gotham City, which are linked to a mysterious figure known as the Riddler. As the body count rises, Batman emerges to investigate and put an end to the Riddler's reign of terror.

Cast
-----

* Robert Pattinson as Bruce Wayne/Batman
* Zoë Kravitz as Selina Kyle/Catwoman
* Paul Dano as Edward Nashton/The Riddler
* Jeffrey Wright as James Gordon
* John Turturro as Carmine Falcone
* Peter Sarsgaard as District Attorney Gil Colson
* Jayme Lawson as Bella Reál
* Andy Serkis as Alfred Pennyworth
* Colin Farrell as Oswald Cobblepot/The Penguin

Production
----------

### Development

#### Early work and initial plans from Ben Affleck

Development on The Batman began in 2014, when Ben Affleck was initially set to direct and star in the film. However, due to scheduling conflicts and creative differences, Affleck eventually dropped out of the project.

#### Redevelopment under Matt Reeves

In 2017, Matt Reeves was hired to take over the project, with a new script and a new direction for the film. Reeves brought a fresh perspective to the Batman franchise, focusing on a more grounded and realistic take on the character.

Writing
------

The screenplay for The Batman was written by Matt Reeves and Chris Terrio. The script was heavily influenced by Reeves' own experiences as a fan of the Batman comics and his desire to create a more nuanced and complex take on the character.

Casting
------

The casting process for The Batman was a lengthy and rigorous process, with Reeves and his team searching for actors who could bring depth and nuance to their characters. Robert Pattinson was eventually cast as Batman, after a series of intense auditions and meetings.

Design
------

### Sets and props

The production design for The Batman was handled by Paul Hotte and Laura Jean Shannon, who created a detailed and immersive world for the film. The sets were designed to be a mix of Gothic and Art Deco styles, reflecting the dark and gritty tone of the film.

### Batsuit

The Batsuit in The Batman was designed by Robert Swindells and Chris Burningham, who drew inspiration from the comics and previous film iterations of the character. The suit was a combination of practical and CGI elements, with Pattinson wearing a full-body spandex suit and a mask to create the iconic image of Batman.

### Other costumes

The costumes for the supporting characters in The Batman were designed by Lindy Hemming, who created a range of complex and detailed costumes for the film. The Riddler's costume, in particular, was a standout, with its intricate details and use of color.

Filming
------

### Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on the production of The Batman, with the film's shoot being delayed and rescheduled multiple times due to lockdowns and restrictions. The cast and crew had to adapt to a new way of working, with safety protocols and social distancing measures in place.

Editing
-------

The editing of The Batman was handled by William Hoy and Tyler Nelson, who worked closely with Reeves to shape the film's narrative and pacing. The edit was a crucial part of the filmmaking process, with the editors working to create a seamless and immersive viewing experience.

Visual effects
------------

The visual effects for The Batman were handled by Double Negative, who created a range of complex and detailed CGI elements for the film. The effects were used to enhance the action sequences, the Batmobile, and the Gotham City environment.

Music
-----

The music for The Batman was composed by Michael Giacchino, who created a haunting and atmospheric score for the film. The score was a key element of the film's tone and mood, with Giacchino drawing inspiration from the Batman comics and previous film iterations of the character.

Marketing
---------

The marketing campaign for The Batman was a multi-faceted effort, with a focus on social media and online advertising. The campaign included a range of promotional materials, including posters, trailers, and character reveals.

Release
-------

### Theatrical

The Batman was released in theaters on March 4, 2022, in the United States and on March 18, 2022, in the United Kingdom. The film was released in IMAX and Dolby Cinema formats, with select theaters offering 3D screenings.

### Home media

The Batman was released on digital platforms on April 18, 2022, and on Blu-ray and DVD on May 24, 2022.

Reception
---------

### Box office

The Batman was a commercial success, grossing over $770 million worldwide. The film was the second-highest-grossing film of 2022, behind only Top Gun: Maverick.

### Critical response

The Batman received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the film's tone, direction, and performances. The film holds a 93% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 8.1/10.

### Accolades

The Batman received several award nominations, including two Academy Award nominations for Best Sound and Best Visual Effects.

Thematic analysis
----------------

### Class conflict and inequality

The Batman explores themes of class conflict and inequality, with the film's antagonist, the Riddler, using his wealth and privilege to commit crimes and exact revenge on the wealthy elite. The film also highlights the struggles of the working class, with the character of Selina Kyle/Catwoman serving as a symbol of resistance against the oppressive systems of power.

### Depiction of Batman

The Batman offers a nuanced and complex take on the character of Batman, exploring his motivations, emotions, and psychological state. The film portrays Batman as a flawed and vulnerable character, rather than a traditional superhero. The film's depiction of Batman has been praised for its depth and nuance, offering a fresh take on the character.

Future
------

### Sequels and shared universe

The success of The Batman has paved the way for a new era of DC Comics films, with several sequels and spin-offs in development. The film's director, Matt Reeves, has been confirmed to return for the sequel, with Robert Pattinson set to reprise his role as Batman.

### Spin-off series

The success of The Batman has also led to the development of several spin-off series, including The Penguin, which is set to be a HBO Max original series. The series will star Colin Farrell as Oswald Cobblepot/The Penguin and will explore the character's backstory and development.

### Unproduced series

Several other spin-off series are in development, including a series focused on the character of Catwoman and a series exploring the world of Gotham City.
